Homage to the Buddha of the Light of the Pure Golden Space Next, pay homage to the great canon of the twelve divisions of the Buddhist canon.
Bow in respect to the great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the ten directions.
Take refuge in the innumerable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the worlds in the ten directions.
Pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.
Take refuge in the innumerable and boundless pratyekabuddhas.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, next repent.
Disciples!
Having already repented the retribution of hell, we should now continue to repent the retribution of the three evil paths.
The Buddha said in the sutra:
Those with much desire suffer much distress due to seeking many benefits.
Those who are content consider even sleeping on the ground to be happiness, while those who are discontented consider even dwelling in heaven to be unsatisfactory.

But worldly people, when suddenly faced with an emergency, can let go of their wealth without considering the amount, yet they do not realize that this body is on the brink of the three evil paths' deep pit, and with one breath not returned, it will certainly fall.
If there are knowledgeable people who teach them to create merit and cultivate future wholesome Dharma provisions, they hold onto this stingy mind and refuse to do anything about it.
Such people are extremely foolish and deluded.
Why is this so?
The Buddha said in the sutra:

'When born, one does not bring a single coin, and when dying, one does not take a single coin. Toiling and accumulating for it, one worries and troubles oneself. It is of no benefit to oneself, but in vain for others. There is no goodness to rely on, no virtue to trust in, and one is doomed to fall into the evil paths after death.'
Therefore, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, we bow our heads and with utmost sincerity take refuge in the Buddha.

We take refuge in the Buddha of Lofty Light in the East, the Buddha of Lotus Supreme in the South, the Buddha of Great Compassion and Light in the West, the Buddha of Flower Mountain Treasury in the North, the Buddha of Buddha's Voice in the Southeast, the Buddha of Utpala Flower Banner in the Southwest, the Buddha of Turning Auspiciousness in the Northwest, the Buddha of Pure Illumination in the Northeast, the Buddha of No Retreat in the Nadir, and the Buddha of Jeweled Virtues in the Zenith. We take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples,

today we will next repent of the karmic retributions of being an animal, which is to be ignorant and unaware;ğŸ”½repenting of the karmic retributions of being an animal, which is to carry heavy loads and be yoked to plows to repay past debts;
repenting of the karmic retributions of being an animal, which is to lack freedom and be slaughtered and cut up by others;
repenting of the karmic retributions of being an animal, which is to have no feet, two feet, four feet, or many feet;
repenting of the karmic retributions of being an animal, which is to be bitten and eaten by small insects in the fur, feathers, scales, and shells of the body.
Repenting of these immeasurable and boundless karmic retributions of being an animal, we take refuge and repent with utmost sincerity today.
Disciples,
today we will next repent of the karmic retributions of being a hungry ghost, which is to be constantly hungry;
repenting of the karmic retributions of being a hungry ghost, which is to never hear the names of drink and water for hundreds of thousands of years;
repenting of the karmic retributions of being a hungry ghost, which is to eat pus, blood, excrement, and filth;
Repent of the karmic retribution of having one's entire body burn with flames when moving in the hungry ghost realm;
Repent of the karmic retribution of having a large belly and a small throat in the hungry ghost realm.
Repent of the immeasurable and boundless suffering and retribution in the hungry ghost realm. For these reasons, we sincerely bow our heads today and take refuge in repentance.
Disciples!
Today we next repent of the karmic retribution of flattery and deception in the realm of all ghosts, spirits, and asuras;
Repent of the karmic retribution of carrying sand, bearing stones, filling rivers, and blocking the sea in the realm of ghosts and spirits;
Repent of the karmic retribution of being born as a ferocious ghost, a kumbhÄá¹‡á¸a, or other evil ghost that devours blood and flesh and receives this ugly appearance.

Repent of the immeasurable and boundless karmic retribution of all offenses in the realm of ghosts and spirits. Today we bow our heads to the Buddhas in the ten directions and the Bodhisattvas of the great earth, seeking their compassion and repentance so that they may all be eradicated.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting of the karmic retributions of the animal realm and so forth, wish to be free from the defilements of ignorance in life after life, to recognize the causes of their karma, to be illuminated by wisdom, and to end the bodies of the evil destinies.

May the merit generated from repenting of the karmic retributions of the hungry ghosts and so forth be used to wish that in life after life they may forever be free from the suffering of greed, hunger, and thirst, and always eat the flavor of nectar and liberation.

May the merit generated from repenting of the karmic retributions of ghosts, asuras, and so forth be used to wish that in life after life they may be honest and without flattery, free from the causes of wrong livelihood and the effects of ugly appearances, and bring blessings to humans and gods.

May the disciples from now until the attainment of the Way definitely not receive the retributions of the four evil destinies, except out of great compassion for sentient beings, to dwell there without aversion through the power of vows.
The Sutra of the Monk Baodai's Questions and Answers on the Retributions of the Lotus Treasure Vehicle, Part 1: Baodai then entered another collapsing and burying hell.
Why is it called the collapsing and burying hell?

The prison is forty-nine yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls, and at the four corners of the iron walls there are vajra mountains. When a powerful wind comes and blows the mountains together, they grind the prisoners to dust, like scattered sand with no space in between.
Fire emerges from the mountains, blazing and burning, spreading throughout the prison without rest. Iron spears are scattered everywhere, stabbing the sinners, and the spears are all on fire.
At that time, in the northern gate, there were three thousand sinners who raised their voices in great wailing and threw themselves to the ground, saying:
What sins have we committed to come into this place?
The horse-headed rakshasa grabbed an iron mace and struck their heads, leading them to the prison.
In the center of the prison there were four great iron dogs, one yojana tall, with their mouths wide open and fire burning inside their mouths.
When the sinners approached, the dogs would growl in anger. The crowd of sinners, hearing this roar, immediately became frightened and collapsed on the ground in a daze for a long time.
The hot wind blows, and sharp knives cut the body, causing it to scatter. The pain is unbearable, so they run towards the horns.
The vajra iron mountains naturally move and collapse, pressing down on the sinners. The bodies of the sinners immediately dissolve.
The prison guards and yakshas kick the sinners with large iron pikes, and when they call out alive, they revive on their own.
In this way, the pain is a myriad of hardships. For a day and a night, the sinners suffer countless torments. They cannot find life or death.
Baota asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
For what sins did these sinners come to enter this hell?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied to Baota Bodhisattva:

These people were unable to maintain their minds and practice austerities to seek blessings. Instead, they relied on powerful clans and relied on official positions, playing with the wise and bullying the poor and lowly.
They either wrongfully took others' wealth and treasures, or deceitfully robbed others' family property and livelihood, with no sense of shame.

For this reason, they fall into hell, and for hundreds of thousands of lifetimes have no chance of escape. Later, if they escape, they will be born in borderlands or low castes, and will not get to hear the Buddha's true Dharma.
When Baodai heard this, he wept and left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
